awd_titl_txt: Materials development for mid-infrared plasmonic applications
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professors Stefan Franzen and Jon-Paul Maria of the North Carolina State University to explore how plasmon oscillations in the mid-infrared (IR) spectrum can interact with molecular vibrations to enhance the infrared characterization science. To accomplish this goal, the team implements extreme-mobility conductive metal oxides into thin film platforms that support surface plasmon resonance phenomena, and determines how to functionalize them for specific chemical attachments. Broader impacts of this work include scientific impacts well beyond this project, such as (i)the development of  new methods to enhance sensing by mode mixing an IR plasmon and an IR absorption band, and (ii) merging IR surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy with fluorescence to monitor surface reactions at the monolayer scale.  Educational broader impacts are to be achieved by  providing a training ground for graduate students in an interdisciplinary, collaborative research environment.

This project merges complementary capabilities in Chemistry and Materials Science that may enable new chemical sensing capabilities. For example, the members of this collaborative research team seek to attach photoactive oligonucleotides to CdO:Dy films using new SAM chemistries and monitor binding simultaneously using fluorescence and mid-IR plasmonic detection. Heretofore, such strategies have generally not been seen using conventional plasmonic materials such as gold nanoparticles that quench fluorescence events. The team is also exploring new plasmonic oxides other than CdO with promising mobility and surface chemistry properties. The experiments include thin film preparation by molecular beam epitaxy and sputtering, film characterization by diffraction, infrared-ellipsometry, and electronic transport. Surface functionalization of these layers utilizes approaches based on chemical attachment with and without ultra-thin interface layers prepared by atomic layer deposition.

por.por_cntn:
The research in this proposal has extended the study of plasmonic surfaces to the mid-infrared, the region of the spectrum where molecular vibrations and heat can be detected. Plasmonic surfaces refer to excitation of conduction electrons by light. Normally, we think of conductors as being reflectors or mirrors. But gold has a yellowish color because of a plasmonic interaction with light. This research has extended that type of interaction in a conductor to the infrared region.  This is a relatively new field and there is much to understand in terms of theory, but also mid-infrared plasmonic materials are being developed as a new generation of materials used in electronic sensing and switching.

We modified a commercially available instrument to be able to observe changes in the reflection of light in the mid-infrared region. A figure shows a holder and sample chamber that are placed in the beam path of a mid-infrared variable angle spectroscopic ellipsometer (IR-VASE). This method has proven to be the most accurate for research purposes.  

In this research, we have developed doped-cadmium oxide as a new material capable of supporting mid-infrared plasmons. We have proven that interaction using the optical signal from nitrous oxide gas in contact with the surface. We can observe the nitrous oxide gas signal in the plasmonic absorption of the conducting surface. The primary figure shows the percent reflection of light that demonstrates a change of phase in observed bending mode of nitrous oxide as it interacts with the plasmon. The nitrous oxide spectrum has two bands and those shift from an absorption to a dispersion as the angle of incident light passes through the plasmon absorption of doped-cadmium oxide. This is a direct observation of differences in the phase of the interaction between the vibrations of the gas molecule and the electronic oscillations in the surface. Another figure shows three different views of the same phenomenon in terms of absorption. There is a large shift observed as a function of angle precisely when the system crosses the plasmon absorption. This unexpected phenomenon is unique to plasmonic interactions and potentially has applications since the phase can be changed merely be changing the angle of incident light. Aside from the fundamental interest in how two different material phases interact optically, this type of interaction can be used in optoelectronic switching.

This research has positively impacted theoretical understanding, practical development of new processes, training and education. We have developed both the experimental capability and understanding of the theory to the point where we can predict new materials that have similar properties. Doped cadmium oxide is an excellent test material, but is unlikely to be the material needed for semiconductor and other real world applications.  Two graduate students were trained and received PhD degrees supported by this project. Both accepted positions in industry immediately following their PhD defense. We have run a one-day workshop for high school students on the North Carolina State University campus. Students participated in nine different demonstration sessions. They learned how light interacts with matter and many applications and were introduced to career opportunities in science and engineering.
